title: 104_hr3510
content: The Act titled "Women's Pension Equity Act of 1996" includes provisions for a model spousal consent form and qualified domestic relations order. The Women's Pension Equity Act of 1996 includes provisions for a model spousal consent form and qualified domestic relations order, amending the Internal Revenue Code and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. The form must be developed by the Secretary by January 1, 1997, written in plain language, and disclose whether the waiver is irrevocable or can be revoked by a qualified domestic relations order. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to develop a spousal consent form by January 1, 1997, under the Women's Pension Equity Act of 1996. The form must be easily understood and disclose whether the waiver is irrevocable or can be revoked by a qualified domestic relations order. Additionally, a model qualified domestic relations order form must be developed by the Secretary by the same date. The Secretary of Labor is required to develop a form by January 1, 1997, for a qualified domestic relations order that meets specific requirements and focuses on certain provisions. This is in addition to the spousal consent form and model qualified domestic relations order form mandated by the Women's Pension Equity Act of 1996. The Secretary of Labor and the Secretary of the Treasury are required to publicize model forms related to pension outreach efforts. Extension of Tier II Railroad Retirement benefits to surviving former spouses pursuant to divorce agreements is amended under the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974. An annuity portion can be paid to a surviving former spouse as per a court decree of divorce, annulment, or legal separation without termination upon the death of the individual who earned the annuity. This amendment takes effect upon the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Survivor annuities for widows, widowers, and former spouses of federal employees who die before attaining age for deferred annuity under Civil Service Retirement System. Benefits for Widow or Widower under Section 8341(f) of title 5, United States Code are amended to include provisions for former employees with deferred annuities who die before claiming annuity, ensuring their surviving spouse receives benefits. Section 8341(h) of title 5, United States Code is amended to provide survivor annuity benefits for former spouses of former employees who die before claiming annuity, as specified in an election under section 8339(j)(3) or court order. The Office shall provide regulations for the application of survivor benefit rights to the widow, widower, or surviving former spouse of a former employee who dies after separating from service with title to a deferred annuity under section 8338(a) but before establishing a valid claim for annuity. The amendments provide survivor annuity benefits for former employees who die after separating from service but before establishing a valid claim for annuity. The effective date is the enactment of the Act and applies only to those who die on or after that date. Court orders regarding federal retirement benefits for former spouses of federal employees are addressed in Section 5. Section 8345(j) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include payment to former spouses of federal employees under court decrees or orders. Lump-sum benefits under Section 8342 are also subject to this amendment. The amendment includes provisions for payment to former spouses of federal employees under court decrees or orders, as well as lump-sum benefits under Section 8342. The effective date of these amendments is upon the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. Prevention of circumvention of court order by waiver of retired pay for civil service retirement annuity. Prevention of circumvention of court order by waiving retired pay for civil service retirement annuity. An amendment to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability System allows military service to be credited as service only if the employee authorizes deduction and payment to the former spouse as per court order. The amendment allows military service to be credited as service for civil service retirement annuity only if the employee authorizes deduction and payment to the former spouse as per court order.
